Dear India, 

      It seems that no matter what day I flip open my paper or go to one of the various online news sources I regularly check, I see another special interest, medical anomaly from one of the villages in your fine country, India. Babies with two faces, babies with eight legs, children with tumors on their face that way in excess of 10 lbs... you folks got it all! Don't get me wrong, India, I'm not here to chastise you for your medical anomalies, in fact no one should be chastising you these days. In a world where the constant fears of nuclear war, holy wars, and the "demoralization of our children", you folks seem to be getting something right. Your economy is growing more everyday, your business men are growing savvier thanks to globalization, and your medical school students come to our country to learn our methods and then take them back to your country to improve your own hospitals. Now I'm sure many of my country's people believe that you're stealing jobs away from us, but I'll openly commend you for your methods. If anything, I'm envious of your people because an expensive operation like a triple bypass surgery costs tens of thousands of dollars, in your country it only costs a fraction of that. I'd hop on a plane and get my surgery in your country if I ever needed to, but my government has made that illegal. 
      Another thing I'd love to commend you on is the treatment of the children who are born with such bizarre deformities. Heck, in my country someone in a wheelchair can still be stared at in horror, but not in your country. If I remember correctly, it warmed my heart when I found out that your country's people treated a child that was born with eight limbs like a goddess. Oddly enough, if that little girl was born in my country she would be carted around to every day time talk show currently on the air so everyone could get a slice from the octo-girl pie. Now at face value I'm sure these look the same, but I assure you they're not. In your country, this little girl was a goddess, she was praised and seen as a good omen. In my country, she'd just be a "medical anomaly" which is just a sugar-coated way of saying "freak". In all honesty, India, I could probably write on and on about how amazing your country is from what I've read and how amazing it would be to see it with my own eyes, but I think this will do it. Nothing too thoughtful, nothing too provoking... just that I think my people could learn a lot from your's. 

 - Corey

I answer phones, make copies, and listen to professors as they tell me that they're heading out for lunch and that they would be back in an hour. Occasionally they throw me a curve ball and I have to call the repair guys or get the mail or something. Ultimately, though, it's all one big ball of boring. Anyway, some people turn to me and asked if I watched the game. Of course I didn't, I watched the Mythbusters marathon last night and it was incredibly satisfying. I can't sleep. I'm dead tired, but I can't sleep. Something today really got under my skin and really disgusted me. I don't know, maybe I'm too compassionate.

In my Accounting class, I shared my book with a woman I had spoken to a little before in previous semesters. I had no problem sharing my book with her, but I was suprised I needed to. She had always been responsible and would've never left her book behind accidently. Anyway, after class, I offered to print copies of the pages we needed for homework for her, but she declined. She said she was going to see if the bookstore had any used copies of the book for sale. She said it was stupid that she was too scared to go home and get her book. Then I put two and two together, and added in her black eye. Chances are that someone whether it be a husband, a boyfriend, or a family member had done that. Ever since I left class that's been riding on my mind. 

I hate it. It's why I hate Aaron as much as I do. I hate domestic abuse. I hate the fact that this woman is too scared to go to her own house to pick up her book and would rather by a new book instead. What bullshit is it that she can't feel safe in her own home? I know from experience, it's one of the most degrading feelings in the world. Your home is supposed to be the one place in the world you're supposed to feel safe, yet you'll do anything you can to stay away from it. Hell, I made it a daily habit to have somewhere else to go everyday after school for almost a year. I can't understand how someone can do that type of thing to someone they "love". It's odd, the more these crimes get turned in, the less jail time anyone seems to serve. In fact, if you want to make sure that they do go to jail, make sure they are wanted for a dozen other crimes. The law doesn't care about people, apparently. The sad part is that I know way too many women who've had this happen to them, but this seems to be my state's favorite crime.

Personally, hurting the ones you love is a much more heinous crime than theft or posession, but no one around here seems to care as much as they let on.

Condensed Over-all Update:

Lori and I are going on 8 months which is rad. She's currently feeling sick and playing WoW. 
I quit my job at the gas station and I'm working on campus now. The pay is better and I don't have to do half of the work I did at the store. 
My classes are going way better than they did last year. My Accounting class blows, but if I can squeak by with a C it'll be okay. 

Now, for a decent update. Yesterday I skipped school and work to sleep in and hang out with Lori. I got to the mall an hour early though, so I chatted with Tabbi at the book store and met a guy whose name escapes me at the moment. He chatted with me about how the college system was bullshit and how he was 12 years older than me and had been around the world. He told me how he was $70,000 in debt, but he had a plan, you see. His plan? Move to Canada and become a citizen. After hanging around Canada for 2-3 years, he'd move back and become an American citizen again and recieve a new social security number. So, in theory, all of the debt associated with the old social security card are both null and void. Awesome idea in theory, but we'll see how it pays off. 

After prying myself out of conversation with the nameless revolutionary, I wandered around the mall until I called Lori to find out where the little darling was. So, satisified with her answer, I picked a place to hide for my guerilla warfare strike. The Calendar kiosk would have to do. So, while pretending to be interested in the "Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader" day-by-day calendar, I kept my eyes posted on the corner around the Macados were I knew Lori would be coming. Sure enough, after a few moments, there she came in her dinosaur hoodie and as she passed the kiosk in pursuit of me - I pounced. Success! 

After messing around at the mall for a bit, we were off to run some errands and then get some food for our sustainence. After a quick trip to the bank and the gas station, to Applebees we go! Food was good as always and we got to sit in the big, rad chairs. At first we really close to these older people and that was a bit uncomfortable, but after awhile they left. The rest of the time, we ate our edibles and sang along/talked about/danced to the mixture of awesomely good/bad songs to not-so-awesomely bad songs.

Then, off to the shopping. We went to Wal*Mart, joked around there for a bit, and then we went to a comic book shop that was on Mercer St. that we hadn't been to. Now Lori may be nicer about it, but the place was just sad. They didn't have alot of anything, most of the stuff didn't have prices, and the hired help wasn't too much help. Basically, it was like some people found some boxes of comic books in their basements and decided to open a store. Lori found a used Neil Gaimen (probably fucked up the spelling to that) book that she wanted, but the gal at the counter couldn't find a price so she didn't sell it to Lori. Now, unless this book was the first edition of the fucking bible or whatever, I think she could've come up with a price in her head. Hell, five or seven bucks should've been enough, but nope, Lori didn't get the book and they didn't get any business. After that we headed to Cheap Thrills which is always an adventure I personally enjoy because I know that they always have this Henry Rollins Spoken Word cd for sale and, by god, I'm going to buy it. So I enter the store and like a heat seeking missle, I head to the used bin and BOOM... mission accomplished. So, I also picked up the Horrors' cd (also from the used bin) and Lori satisfied her love for British transvestittes and nerdy, Canadian country singers by picking up Little Shop of Horrors on DVD and a David Bowie cd. 

So we hop in the car and head back to Lori's house o'cats and raccoons to get the alotted time of cuddling and lovin's in. So, while at Lori's house, I check out the Rollins' cd and realize why it's always in the used bin... one of the two cds in it, is ACDC's Back in Black... not exactly what I was looking for. Oh well, the one cd is badass enough. So, while at Lori's house, we cuddled and loved on one another and watched the Emperor's New Groove. You know, I have no idea how I've made it this far without seeing that movie. I love Patrick Werburton and his funny, but loveable role as Kronk. The movie was just rad as hell and I'm just really happy Lori showed me it. 

I really need to tell my paranoia to shut the fuck up sometimes. She loves me so much that she'll show me cartoons and feel comfortable geeking out around me. Oh, and we're going to see They Might Be Giants and Regina Spektor next month in Charleston. Just two days after we're going to see Beowulf. 

On an unrelated note, Lori has gotten me into reading Kurt Vonnegut. I just finished Slaughterhouse Five earlier this week and I'm eager to read more. 

Well, that's all for now. I'll update this thing again maybe on a regular basis.

Corey

PS: I professed my love for Henry Rollins and Patrick Werburton in this update. I suppose I love big muscle-bound men... weird.

Outdoors is a deck full of teenagers aged 15 to 21. My sister is having a party for no apparent reason, but that's all well and good. Unlike my oldest sister who made a big deal to go out there and join in on the party, I'm staying inside with my Gus. He needs the company. 

I miss Lori. alot. It's so foreign to go from spending a day with someone who understands you and grasps you without having to explain anything to her. I hope one day I can make her realize just how much of a miraculous feet that is and hopefully repay that debt to her. I'll never be able to understand how Kevin didn't find her marvelous... the very notion that someone can't appreciate how amazing she is frustrates me. Here's the girl who picks up the phone to call me, just as soon as I call her. She knows what I'm talking about or knows the answers to questions I haven't finished asking. Words can't express how brilliant her eyes look while I'm staring into them... staring deep down into her pupils like they're the endless sea of stars in space. I've always thought of myself as a bad astronaut who always turns left when it was probably better to turn right... but when it comes to Lori, I feel like I'm right on course. The very fact that I can only experience this comfort once a week is a pain, but always gives me something to look forward to. 

Sometimes I forget that I'm alive. Allow me to elaborate. Sometimes, there are things in the world that absolutely stun me or fascinate me to the point that I forget that I am Corey Flanagan. I just stare off into space and think about how bizarre and strange existance is. For instance, somewhere, right now... someone is dying from blood loss. Do you think they're too stunned from whatever caused them to bleed that they don't think about their impending demise? Or are they stunned because they realize what's happening and they're thinking back on lost loves, past regrets, and everything else? On the other end of the spectrum, right now someone is realizing whatever is going on in their life is not what they want to be and are being reborn? I dunno, I think I think too much about things like that.

There, that should do it. So, here goes my entry about yesterday.

Yesterday morning I woke up at 5 to study for my Economics exam that I had at 8 in the morning. So, got my shit together, took it, and I should've done better to make a long story short. I probably made a low B or C in the class, but seriously, I hate economics. Then, I had about an hour and a half to kill before my Business Communications exam at 10. Well, in the process of studying, I was trapped into an hour long discussion with this older woman in my class named Saltana. Yes, Saltana. Well, she's the type of older student who loves to re-iterate her life story and just how hard it is to be an older student. Funny thing is, she's 26 and my buddy Kim is 28. Yet Kim is sweet as pie and chill as fuck. Well, whatever, the exam was easy as hell after I found out that I made all A's on the three resumes I had to turn in earlier that week. 

The next big notable section is my day at work, and baton down the hatches, this was a hell of a day at work. Well, it was fine til this black lady and her sidekick strolled in and tried to buy beer. The truth is, she looked old enough to buy it, but we've been told that we don't card enough, so I asked the lady if she had her id. She said no. So, I told her that I can't sell it. Now, children, allow me to sidetrack for one second and teach you a lesson that you will need to know when you get older. *clears throat* Do NOT get between a black woman and her alcohol. Lord knows she needs whatever help she can get as she pushes through her mundane, lower-middle class existance. Now, that may sound racist, but that's just how 95% of the black population in this city roll. So, does she oblige with the law, put back the beer, and head out the door? No. She proceeds to claim that I've never asked her for her ID before and that we need to start enforcing the rules all of the time. So, I tell her that the rules state that she needs to show me her ID if I ask for it and if she doesn't oblige, I can't sell it to her. She then responds by asking for my manager (who is my older sister) and upon finding out that she wasn't in the store, she then threatens to "smash my mouth in." I proceed to say "What for? For doing my job?" She blows off said logic and threatens to call the police. Now, I knew the law was clearly on my side in this event, so I told her that she was free to do so. So, she "calls the police" and heads outside to try to intimidate me. In the process of that, I called my sister who actually did call the police. Well, as soon as the ladies outside heard that the police were really coming, they left. When the cops showed up, they told me to call them the next time they came in causing a ruckus. After that, I had a headache for the rest of the shift from dealing with dumbasses. Note, this occured the second hour of my six hour shift. 

After work I was supposed to hang out with Amanda and the returning but soon departing Beth, but Amanda pulled out. So, Beth picked me up after work and we lounged around East River Mountain Overlook talking about life and friends. Beth cut her bihawks off and now looks exactly like she did when I first met her. So, between that and driving around listening to Alkaline Trio, I had the weirdest sense of Deja Vu. She's leaving tomorrow morning for Ohio where she'll spend her summer working at Cedar Point. When she comes back, she'll be in town for one day before she has to go back to Emory for soccer and school. Although she's caused me alot of pain, frustration, and anger... I can't say that I won't miss her this summer. 

I can say, however, that I'll be spending summer with the raddest girl in specs I've ever met! I can't wait till she gets done with exams so we can see each other more than just on the weekends. My poor Lori is applying for a job and I hope she does well. I sometimes feel like I'm trying to be so protective of her, but all that's done for me in the past is push people away from me. I can't help it, though, I just adore the girl so much that I'd rather see streams of blood pouring from my veins than have to see a single tear roll down her smooth cheek. She's my counter-part... the Pearl Forrester to my Observer. The Brak to my Exeter. It's been 2 months already, but it's hard to imagine how I was before I met her. 

Oh well, enough bragging about the dame for now. Goodnight my lovelys.

As I sit here alone in my room, fingernails and skin still caked in mud and decayed leaves, I've slowly realized that everything is starting to slow down again. That once magical high is wearing off and now the stunning realization about my current status is really hitting hard. 

I feel sick inside and currently out. Perhaps I'm being over-dramatic, but honestly, who is going to care if I am? Everyone else is outside now... living their lives in the most debaucherous and care-free ways more than likely. I could never understand why someone would be so interested in tearing themselves down from the inside out. I could never understand how my peers could pursue the opposite (or same) sex for nothing more than for some physical need to be met. Are we really all such animals at heart? It's both disgusting and disturbing to watch all of the self-destruction around me, but what's even more disgusting and disturbing is that they are all having fun. Here I am, with my oh-so-precious morals and sincerety miserable and alone on a weekend night. I hate people. I hate how they make me feel so alienated and ill-at-ease inside myself. I've never been sure if people really understood or knew me as well as they think. 

I'm sensitive and I try to hide it, but ultimately it's impossible to do so. I'm tired of giving myself out only to be stepped on. I don't trust many people anymore. I wanted to believe that everyone is good at heart, but I was wrong. Loyalty... faith... trust... all things out of a fairytale that I've tried to make out of my life. I try so hard to be knoble, but have nothing to show for it. Uncertainty and self-doubt frequently grate away at my wits and my nerve and I'm scared of becoming this bitter person who hates everything. 

Who knows... this could all be shit that's just building up inside my own mind. My brain betrays me like that. She couldn't understand how life is like when you're constantly fearing the worst, dreading the worst, and eventually the worst happening because you've been fretting on it so fucking long. I'm tired of being pushed away. It seems as if people are so scared of damaging me that they don't want to take a chance or they want to lay me down gently. Am I really that unstable, people? Do you really have that much confidence in my mental health that you think if you screw me over I'll snap?

Sometimes I think my life would be so much easier if I could just disconnect myself, you know? If there was some way that I could unplug my brain partially so all I think about is work and school. Everything else... thoughts, emotions, dreams... all would be ignored. I daydream too much. I'm pretty sure these days that no one has let me down. I've just played out these fantasies in my head long enough that when things don't go according to "plan", I let myself down. 

I suppose one of my better qualities has always been my story-telling ability. Mainly because I have so many stories worth telling. I've told everyone the funny ones. You know, awkward sexual experiences and embarrassing stories from my youth. I'm pretty sure only one or two people have heard the more serious ones. For a kid my age, I've been through alot of serious things that most of you have no clue about. I've never had a near-death experience myself (though I curiously want to have a minor one), but I've seen my fair share. Someone ODing is perhaps the scariest thing you'll ever see. The way their eyes roll back into their skull... the shade of milk white their now cold, clammy skin turns... how their lips turn shades of blue, purple, and black. It's terrifying. We all think that we're young and indestructible, but we couldn't be further from the truth. Once again, I'm probably being over-dramatic. 

See, most of you will be coming in from your exciting Saturday night/Sunday morning, read this, and will write it off as Corey venting his frustrations, and it's true. I honestly am because there is so little positive around me anymore. I don't blame any of you for my current state. You're living your life. I, on the otherhand, have this severe inability to do that. 

Like my profile says, I'm always going to be that weird kid who swears people are staring at him, that when a group of people circle around eachother that they are talking about him, that can't help but doubt the words that come out of others' mouths. There are two people in the world that I trust with my heart. Both live hundreds or thousands of miles away. That's scary for me. I'm sure they are sick of talking to me anyway.

Well, to those of you who have been reading my lj for the past few years, I've finally done it, I went to Warped Tour. More on that later.

Monday:

Dave picked me up bright and early so that I could help take his dogs to the kennels and one to the vet. Dave has some big dogs. At one point he got out of the car and left me alone with them...they must've smelled fear on me or something because they just walked all over me. I had so much dog hair on me it looked like on of them exploded. After that we headed to the Enigk's where we (The Hudaks minus Ryan and Adam, Ali, The Enigks, Dave, Michael, Brett, Katie, and myself) left for Cleveland. Many hours (and one kickass lunchbreak) later, we arrived in Cleveland and it was so great to be out of a car. We walked over to the mall where I bought a Star Wars shirt with a stormtroopers helmet on it with two bones behind it, and a bloody Misfit shirt. After some more shenanigans, we walked back to the hotel. We ordered pizza, worked on a punkrock crossword puzzle, played frisbee in the lobby, got in trouble for playing frisbee in the lobby, and then went to sleep after rubberband wars and plastic spoon throwing.

Tuesday: 

That morning we got up and got ready for Cedar Point. Well, it was pretty cool and we rode some pretty fucking scary rides (I'm afraid of heights). As soon as we got in ride for the Raptor, though, Dave Matthews Band was playing and Brett said, "Man, this isn't amusement park music, this is ABUSEment park music." Brett had me rolling the whole day. Well, after he said that, Me First and the Gimme Gimmes came on so we all sang along and marked out. I found that the best part of the day was when we were in line for rides and we could sing along to songs that were playing. They actually played "Freebird" by Lynrd Skynrd the whole way through. We ate lunch and dinner in the picnic area. I bought a tie-dye shirt that says "The Raptor" there too. After the park, we drove closer to the airport in Cleveland to stay at the other hotel. We ended up ordering pizza there too. So, two nights in a row we had pizza.

Wednesday:

We ventured into the Body Worlds Exhibit and the Rock N Roll Hall of Fame. Both were pretty cool, but I've never been a museum type. The dead bodies looked like jerky. They let little kids into the rest of the museum, so it's safe to say that the rest of the museum day was shot. Well, we went to the Rock N Roll hall of fame which was pretty cool. I marked out for all the Buddy Holly, B-52, and DEVO stuff they had. I want to see The Who's "Tommy" now though. If any knows where I could find a copy, it'd be cool. I bought a Dickies cd in the gift shop because those are really hard to find. We ate another picnic between the two museums and headed back to the hotel for a little while where we went swimming (I swam in a dress shirt and tie). We then went to Rachel's Aunt's house for dinner (oddly enough, more pizza 3 nights in a row). We walked to the beach of Lake Erie from her house and hung out there. Rachel's cousins didn't like me and poured sand in my hair after Dave tackled me (after I tackled him of course). We walked to some ice cream shop later (but right after Michael fell in Lake Erie off of some rocks). Well, I wanted to find some reasonably priced coca-cola in Ohio so we (Beth, Me, Sarah, Ali, Brett, and Katie) walked to a Rite-Aid that was across the street. Well, while there, some crazy woman tried to sell us shirts (she didn't even work there). Well, we ran off to hide in the tampon aisle, well Rite-Aid called security on us (do they even have security?) so we ran into the hair care aisles. Beth and I found some hair dye which we purchased and left Rite-Aid with the others. We walked back to Rachel's Aunts singing "Ole!" by the Bouncing Souls and then we stayed at her house until close to midnight. When we got back to the hotel, we ate more pizza and Beth, Dave, and I dyed our hair (Beth did Red, Dave and I did Orange).

Thursday:

WARPED TOUR! We rode the RTA to get there which was awkward because it was full of punks and Cleveland Indian fans. We got there and immediately went to the Hurley stage to see Motion City Soundtrack (we were really close btw). I didn't really care for the band beforehand, but they won me over with their performance. After that we caught a bit of the Matches before me and Beth wandered around aimlessly. We ended up finding our way back to the Hurley stage where the Horrorpops were setting up. We stood there for 20 minutes unril they plugged in (before then, however, the singer for Riverboat Gamblers harassed a fan near us who called them emo. It was quite funny). We were right up front on the barracade when they started. I got so many great pics and Kamilla was playing to me and beth the whole time. She's hysterical to watch on stage. Beth got one of the buttons they threw into the crowd. The Horrorpops were such a fun band who played to us and the rest of the crowd. Well, after them, we tried to see Transplants but I didn't want to stand in a large crowd so we went to the Ernie Ball stage to catch the future gods of ska, Big D and the Kids Table who not only made fun of Avenge Sevenfold, but all the hardcore bands with their performance. They closed their set with L.A.X. which was an awesome way to go out. From then, we waited up front of the Mike Stage to see MXPX for 30 minutes. Well finally they played and it was awesome, everything I expected (even if Yuri seemed a little tired). The only thing i didn't like was somebody headbutted Beth and I was going to go after him. The thing was that it was so damn hot that I was feeling really dizzy so we (our group) stumbled out of the crowd to sit down in the shade. Michael and Katie were also feeling sick so they left. There a guy sold me a cd for his alternative hip hop band. He was very serious and compassionate which is something I admired so I forked out the 3 bucks for the cd (Arcane, it's really good. Check them out if you can). Well we all chilled out for the next hour or so when some rather cool things happened. 1) I was wearing my Raptor shirt and this chick came up to me and told me that she actually operated that ride at Cedar Point. 2) My back was hurting and i wanted to lean against a tree but there was a girl already there and I didn't want to sit beside someone I didn't know. Well, an hour later she asked me if my name was Corey. IT WAS HEATHER! Lol, that was pretty cool. She told me that Liz told her to look out for me. (thnx mommy!) Well after she left, the guys held down the fort under the shade (provided by the fans of Hawthorne Heights who wanted to meet their idols) while the girls went to see All-American Rejects. I watched this Rap group called Bad Fathers who were just these guys in loin clothes rapping. They were pretty damn cool and ballsy at that. Well the girls returned and I attempted to see The Offspring but gave up so we waited for Ali and Sarah to watch Thrice so we could leave. We rode the RTA back to the station, got in the MAZDA and drove back to the hotel where we all went swimming to cool down. We ate pizza (4 for 4 people) and sat around in each others rooms and chilled out. I bought a Motion City Soundtrack shirt, a Warped Tour shirt, a Horrorpops shirt (which I bought from Kamilla), a Big D and the Kid's Table shirt, an Aquabats cd and alot of free shit.

Friday:

We woke up feeling the effects of sunburn (mine turned into freckles) and we didn't go out til around noon. We walked to Dunkin' Donuts and Arbys (which was beside the hotel and was open til 1am so we really didn't have to have pizza all those times). We went to a used book and music store, best buy, and the mall (I didn't really find anything). We went back to the hotel, changed clothes, and went to Max and Irma's for dinner. After that we went swimming, hot-tubbing, I went on a nice long walk with Beth where we had a great, deep conversation. After that, all the guys (Myself, Michael, Dave, and Brett) stayed up all night talking about our opinions and ourselves. It was really educational. 

Saturday:

We all cleaned up, packed the cars, and came back home. Beth and I went to Wal*Mart to develop my film.

So, that was my trip in tons of detail. Good luck and good night!

People change. It's a fact, something that is true and cannot be changed no matter how much we want it to...especially these days. I look at the same people I've been awkwardly gawking out for the past years and it seems that I'm staring at total strangers. My best friends have become my enemies, all while my enemies became my best friends. It's ridiculous how a inocent christian girl can become a booze-guzzling, cynical whore. All the while, a friend of mine who I loved to be around spreads more rumors about me than anyone else. The guy at school I used to despise is now my partner in crime. The girl who I thought was extremely independent now depends on her boyfriend to dictate her moods. The one who solely depended on me has gone out and started her own life. The guy who I thought was childish is now one of my closest friends. The band I swore my allegience to is giving me a headache. The nerdy girl I would playfully tease is now the hysterical girl I playfully tease. People who didn't know me, now go out of their way to talk garbage about me. The happy, optimistic friend is still that optimistic. The guy I knew little about is a good friend. The guy who I hated is fun to be around which makes me realize that I was just jealous. 

Through all of this, the girl I loved makes me love her more and more everyday.

Even I have changed. The loud, blaring street punk i loved now gives me a headache. I gave up the "tough guy" fascade in exchange for a more sarcastic, casual one. The clothes are more unusual and less street. The hair is flat and long instead of pointy and vertical.

I miss how things used to be with some people but I know there is no turning back. Those people who I once held so dear are now in my past. To those people, I say my final farewell and tip my hat to you.

"Farewell." *Tips hat.*
